Award.AwardTitle: Analysis and Simulation of Extremes and Rare Events in Complex Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is vital to be able to accurately predict the probability of rare and extreme events, such as heatwaves and hurricanes, in particular from climate models and climate data. Better techniques to estimate the probability of rare events and extremes are of obvious benefit to society, and will lead to better planning for floods, heatwaves, and other exigencies. Prediction from computer simulations or from real world data is an extremely challenging task. Brute force simulations by computer are often not feasible; the number of computer simulations it requires to obtain accurate estimates of the probability and form of rare events is too high for this to be a useful method in practice. In addition to this, we typically lack sufficient data to make confident predictions about rare events and extremes from climate records. Two strands of research will be developed. First, to develop a rigorous understanding of a technique from probability called importance sampling in simple mathematical models with the aim to have a firm foundation for their implementation in more realistic and complicated climate models. Importance sampling in a sense makes rare events less rare and allows reliable estimates of rare events in situations where brute force simulations are not feasible. Second, a statistical technique called extreme value theory will be developed in order to allow better estimates of the probabilities of the duration of extremes, such as heatwaves, from climate models and data.

The Principal Investigators will develop a technique from importance sampling called genealogical particle analysis to speed up sampling by making rare events more common. The steps enabling the speedup may be tracked and accounted for to obtain more accurate estimates of rare events with less computational effort. Extreme value theory for physical observables such as temperature, wind velocity and energy for climate models will be developed and tested on simple climate models and extended to determine the probability of the duration of extremes, such as heatwaves, from time series data. Clustering algorithms based on information theory will be developed to sort data from spatially distinct sites to amplify the data available to better predict, for example, heatwaves and cold spells. The investigation will be in part theoretical, numerical and data analytic. Progress in this area would significantly improve our conceptual understanding of rare events and extremes in complex systems such as the climate and our ability to predict their behavior. The investigators past work on extreme value theory has been recognized and cited by meteorologists; it has detailed how extreme value theory should be applied to deterministic models. The current research will be at the interface of applications and of general interest to scientists modeling complex systems. In addition, the project will provide excellent training in probabilistic techniques and data analysis for the graduate students involved in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective was to develop, implement, and analyze novel methods of prediction of rare events and extremes and genealogical particle algorithms (commonly used in physics) based on extreme value theory (from statistics) on simplified yet useful dynamical models and also on real-world data. In particular, we worked on techniques to determine the probability of heat waves, cold spells, hurricane speeds, and other related extreme behavior in climate models and from physical and meteorological data and records.
In this work, the extreme value theory for time-averages, sums, and maxima of sliding windows and other functionals of an observable on a chaotic dynamical system was developed. The research was not only motivated by purely mathematical considerations but also because understanding the extreme value theory of say time-averages on climate models allows estimation of the probability of heat waves and other phenomena that take place over an extended time period. The motivation for this work was to give estimates of the probabilities of sustained periods of weather anomalies such as heat waves, cold spells, or prolonged periods of rainfall in climate models. These estimates are difficult with standard techniques because the number of prolonged periods of high temperatures or rainfall in the observed records is low, so one must extrapolate these probabilities in some way from the data that is available. The PIs developed such algorithms. 
The predictions made by the algorithms and techniques of this work were borne out by numerical simulations on dynamical systems,  the PUMA general climate model, and extensive analysis of rainfall and temperature data from the US, Australia, and Europe. The approach developed was more accurate than extant methods. The intellectual merits were in the development of novel mathematical techniques to predict rare events, while the broader impact of this research was in the dissemination of these methods to a broad scientific community, particularly the climate science community, via journal publications and public talks.  The PIs derived a numerical and probabilistic model representing the emergence and evolution of SARS-CoV-2 variants, informed by data from in-vitro passaging experiments in Vero B4 Cells. They compare numerical simulation results against probability theoretic derivations of the expected probability of and time until the fittest variant becomes fixed in the population. Contrary to the literature surrounding DNA viruses and eukaryotes where probabilities of fitness extremes are often modeled by the exponential decaying tail, they show that the above fitness differences for SARS-CoV-2 are best modeled by a heavy-tailed distribution. They showed that the evolution of SARS-CoV-2 variants in the laboratory is better modeled by an essentially deterministic process rather than a random diffusional one, with the dynamics driven by the fitness difference between the top variants rather than the mechanics of the lab protocol which introduces randomness via a sampling and dilution process. An interesting consequence of this setting is that the number of variants, rather than their proportion, is a better predictor of the probability of fixation of a variant.  In related work, the PIs successfully applied large deviations theory to simulate and predict rare genetic events in large bacterial populations, with a focus on specific rare events of practical interest, in particular the fixation of genotypes with low fitness. This led to quite accurate estimations for the very small probabilities of rare genotype fixation events, which are notoriously hard to estimate.  Our algorithms were tested and compared to the preceding algorithms derived from the large deviations theory.   The PIs also considered the existence and properties of stable laws for observations on random dynamical systems. Stable laws are the analog of the central limit theorem and arise when the observation has a heavy tail or when the system has a long memory effect.  Most physical systems are subject to random perturbations or stochastic effects, yet the theory of heavy-tailed observations on random chaotic systems has not been developed---despite its relevance to financial, engineering, and biological models. The PIs clarified the behavior of stable laws on a wide variety of random dynamical systems, both in the   annealed and quenched regimes.    

 

STEM training in statistics and applied mathematics was provided to   two successful PhD students: Phuong Tran and Yingxue Su. This research has been disseminated to a broad scientific community through 4 published journal articles and 4 submitted journal articles, as well as more than 20 invited talks by the PIs at scientific conferences. The PIs also advised several undergraduate students during the course of this project.

The PIs also integrated material and results related to the proposed research project in their courses. One example is the course Bayesian Inverse Problems and Uncertainty Quantification (MATH 6397) newly developed and taught for the first time in Spring 2023. Some of the software developed under the proposed research has been released to the public. An example for this can be found under https://github.com/scopagroup/greedygeo.
